pull_request.title: Rework of networking handshake with dropping the Runnable interface.

pullrequest.title: Rework of networking handshake with dropping the Runnable interface.

content.raw: Agree, but with some discussion with Lousie last week \(or two weeks ago\), I think it’s best to move Networking out of a system and up to the \`SimulationRunner\` scope \(at least\).  With it purely as a system, it’s a little convoluted to get access to some of the play/pause/step behavior that it will need to have to function completely.  I’m working on a refactor of that right now.
content.html: Agree, but with some discussion with Lousie last week (or two weeks ago), I think it’s best to move Networking out of a system and up to the `SimulationRunner` scope (at least). With it purely as a system, it’s a little convoluted to get access to some of the play/pause/step behavior that it will need to have to function completely. I’m working on a refactor of that right now.

pullrequest.title: Rework of networking handshake with dropping the Runnable interface.

content.raw:
You might have other intentions, but may I suggest the following changes? 

1. Use a `condition` instead of a busy-wait loop. The condition could be triggered by `::Stop` or by the `ClientManager`. You could simplify things by moving the `ClientManager` code into this class, which would roughly be the `Register` and `Unregister` functions.
2. Block on the `condition` and directly call the `WorkLoop` function. I'm not sure why you're creating another thread for the `WorkLoop`.
content.html:
You might have other intentions, but may I suggest the following changes?

  1. Use a condition instead of a busy-wait loop. The condition could be triggered by ::Stop or by the ClientManager. You could simplify things by moving the ClientManager code into this class, which would roughly be the Register and Unregister functions.
  2. Block on the condition and directly call the WorkLoop function. I'm not sure why you're creating another thread for the WorkLoop.

content.raw: Can the `ClientManager` create and maintain its own Node instance? The `NetworkPrimary` does not use the `node` instance, and only passes it to the `ClientManager`.
content.html: Can the ClientManager create and maintain its own Node instance? The NetworkPrimary does not use the node instance, and only passes it to the ClientManager.

content.raw:
If this system is used, it will change the documented behaviour, see `ign-gazebo --help`:

`  -r                     Run simulation on start. The default is false, which starts simulation paused.`

Maybe unpausing is not the best behaviour here, I'm not sure
content.html:
If this system is used, it will change the documented behaviour, see ign-gazebo --help:

-r Run simulation on start. The default is false, which starts simulation paused.

Maybe unpausing is not the best behaviour here, I'm not sure

pull_request.title: Rework of networking handshake with dropping the Runnable interface.

pullrequest.title: Rework of networking handshake with dropping the Runnable interface.

content.raw:
Could this be achieved with a single file with 2 `<world>`s?

~~~
<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.6">
  <world name="distributed_primary">
    <plugin
      filename="libignition-gazebo-network-system.so"
      name="ignition::gazebo::systems::v0::NetworkPrimary">
      <num_clients>2</num_clients>
    </plugin>

    <model name="box">
      <pose>1 2 3 0 0 1</pose>
      <link name="link">
        <collision name="col">
          <geometry>
            <box>
              <size>3 4 5</size>
            </box>
          </geometry>
        </collision>

        <visual name="vis">
          <geometry>
            <box>
              <size>1 2 3</size>
            </box>
          </geometry>
        </visual>
      </link>
    </model>
  </world>
  <world name="distributed_secondary">
    <plugin
      filename="libignition-gazebo-network-system.so"
      name="ignition::gazebo::systems::v0::NetworkSecondary">
    </plugin>
    <plugin filename="libignition-gazebo-physics-system.so"
      name="ignition::gazebo::systems::v0::Physics">
    </plugin>
  </world>
</sdf>
~~~
content.html:
Could this be achieved with a single file with 2 <world>s?

<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.6">
  <world name="distributed_primary">
    <plugin
      filename="libignition-gazebo-network-system.so"
      name="ignition::gazebo::systems::v0::NetworkPrimary">
      <num_clients>2</num_clients>
    </plugin>

    <model name="box">
      <pose>1 2 3 0 0 1</pose>
      <link name="link">
        <collision name="col">
          <geometry>
            <box>
              <size>3 4 5</size>
            </box>
          </geometry>
        </collision>

        <visual name="vis">
          <geometry>
            <box>
              <size>1 2 3</size>
            </box>
          </geometry>
        </visual>
      </link>
    </model>
  </world>
  <world name="distributed_secondary">
    <plugin
      filename="libignition-gazebo-network-system.so"
      name="ignition::gazebo::systems::v0::NetworkSecondary">
    </plugin>
    <plugin filename="libignition-gazebo-physics-system.so"
      name="ignition::gazebo::systems::v0::Physics">
    </plugin>
  </world>
</sdf>

content.raw:
There are two separate world files because I’m currently using that mechanism to to load plugins into the simulation runner.

We may need to add a separate way to add Plugins than loading via the SDF.  I may need to look at how you are doing it in the GUI to find a better way.
content.html:
There are two separate world files because I’m currently using that mechanism to to load plugins into the simulation runner.

We may need to add a separate way to add Plugins than loading via the SDF. I may need to look at how you are doing it in the GUI to find a better way.

content.raw: It looks like `primary_uuid` is never populated, is it needed? If it's not needed, we could consider making the register/unregister services [one-way responders](https://ignitionrobotics.org/api/transport/6.0/services.html).
content.html: It looks like primary_uuid is never populated, is it needed? If it's not needed, we could consider making the register/unregister services one-way responders.

pull_request.title: Rework of networking handshake with dropping the Runnable interface.

pullrequest.title: Rework of networking handshake with dropping the Runnable interface.

content.raw:
Are there plans for `NetworkPrimary` to use its node directly? If not, maybe the node could just be internal to `ClientManager`.

You could also consider having 2 separate nodes for these classes, which is usually what we do with Ignition Transport (but that's not a justification in itself, maybe there are advantages to sharing the node?).
content.html:
Are there plans for NetworkPrimary to use its node directly? If not, maybe the node could just be internal to ClientManager.

You could also consider having 2 separate nodes for these classes, which is usually what we do with Ignition Transport (but that's not a justification in itself, maybe there are advantages to sharing the node?).
